similar: See where I'm going with this?
example:
A: So we link the database and then map the UI... get the picture?
B: Yeah, I see it now. The integration looks smooth.
A: Perfect, let's start coding it then.
B: No doubt, let's get it.
A: Solid progress.
B: Bet.
japanese: 状況（じょうきょう）飲み込（こ）めた？／わかった？
chinese: 明白了吗？ (Míngbai le ma?) / 懂我意思吗？ (Dǒng wǒ yìsi ma?)

example:
A: You look awful! What happened to you?
B: Flu hit me hard last night, stayed up shivering.
A: Stay home and rest, don't spread that.
B: I'm trying, but I have so much to do.
A: Work can wait, health first.
B: You're right, I'm heading back to bed.
japanese: 顔色（かおいろ）悪（わる）いよ／ひどい格好（かっこう）だね
chinese: 你脸色很差 (Nǐ liǎnsè hěn chà) / 你看起来很糟糕 (Nǐ kànqǐlái hěn zāogāo)

example:
A: He said he'll give me a full refund if I send him my password.
B: Don't fall for it! That's a classic scam.
A: Really? He sounded so professional.
B: They all do, man. Just block him already.
A: Good lookin' out, close call.
B: Facts, stay safe out here.
japanese: 騙（だま）されちゃダメだよ
chinese: 别上当 (Bié shàngdàng) / 别被忽悠了 (Bié bèi hūyou le)

example:
A: Should I sign the contract?
B: What's your gut feeling?
A: Something feels off.
B: Then don't sign it.
A: You think?
B: Always trust your gut.
japanese: 直感（ちょっかん）
chinese: 直觉 (Zhíjué) / 第六感 (Dìliùgǎn)

example:
A: I can't decide between these two jobs.
B: Just go with your gut.
A: Logic says Job A, gut says Job B.
B: Job B will make you happier.
A: You're probably right.
B: Logic is overrated sometimes.
japanese: 直感（ちょっかん）に従（したが）いなよ
chinese: 跟着感觉走 (Gēnzhe gǎnjué zǒu) / 相信你的直觉 (Xiāngxìn nǐ de zhíjué)

example:
A: Your impression of him was spot on.
B: I practiced it.
A: It was hilarious.
B: I noticed his little ticks.
A: You should be an actor.
B: Maybe in another life.
japanese: その通（とお）り／完璧（かんぺき）
chinese: 完全正确 (Wánquán zhèngquè) / 说得太准了 (Shuō de tài zhǔn le)

example:
A: He hired me on the spot.
B: That's amazing!
A: I was shocked.
B: You must have impressed him.
A: I just was myself.
B: Best strategy.
japanese: その場（ば）ですぐに／即座（そくざ）に
chinese: 当场 (Dāngchǎng) / 即兴 (Jíxìng) (if music/speech)

example:
A: Why did you ask me that in front of everyone?
B: I didn't mean to put you on the spot.
A: I froze up completely.
B: Sorry, I thought you knew the answer.
A: Next time, warn me.
B: Won't happen again.
japanese: 困（こま）らせる／追（お）い詰（つ）める
chinese: 让人难堪 (Ràng rén nánkān) / 让人下不来台 (Ràng rén xià bu lái tái)

example:
A: Who's that guy?
B: That's my homie from Queens.
A: He seems cool.
B: Yeah, we go way back.
A: Introduce me.
B: Sure, come say hi.
japanese: ダチ／親友（しんゆう）
chinese: 死党 (Sǐdǎng) / 哥们儿 (Gēmenr) / 老铁 (Lǎotiě)

example:
A: Wanna play games?
B: Can't, I gotta run some errands.
A: Boring.
B: Adulting sucks.
A: Call me when you're done.
B: Will do, give me two hours.
japanese: 野暮用（やぼよう）を済（す）ませる／お使（つか）いに行（い）く
chinese: 去办点杂事 (Qù bàn diǎn záshì) / 跑腿 (Pǎotuǐ)

example:
A: It's getting late.
B: Yeah, we should hit the road.
A: Before traffic gets bad.
B: Did you pack the snacks?
A: Got 'em.
B: Let's roll.
japanese: 出発（しゅっぱつ）する／出（で）かける
chinese: 上路 (Shànglù) / 出发 (Chūfā)

example:
A: I'm going to Coachella!
B: Have a blast!
A: I'm so excited.
B: Drink water, stay safe.
A: I will, mom.
B: Send pics.
japanese: 思（おも）いっきり楽（たの）しんで
chinese: 玩得开心 (Wán de kāixīn) / 嗨翻天 (Hāi fāntiān)

example:
A: *poking arm*
B: Cut it out!
A: I'm just annoying you.
B: It's working.
A: You love me though.
B: Debatable right now.
japanese: いい加減（かげん）にして／やめて
chinese: 省省吧 (Shěngsheng ba) / 够了 (Gòu le)

example:
A: Here's your receipt.
B: Thanks, have a good one.
A: You too.
B: *walks out*
A: Next in line!
B: (to self) Finally got my coffee.
japanese: じゃあね／良（よ）い一日（いちにち）を
chinese: 祝你愉快 (Zhù nǐ yúkuài) / 回见 (Huíjiàn)

example:
A: Why is the train stopped?
B: Beats me.
A: It's been twenty minutes.
B: Maybe signal problems.
A: I'm gonna be late.
B: Welcome to the subway.
japanese: さっぱり分（わ）からない
chinese: 难倒我了 (Nándǎo wǒ le) / 我哪知道 (Wǒ nǎ zhīdào)

example:
A: Bu!
B: Ah! My heart skipped a beat.
A: Did I scare you?
B: Yes, don't do that.
A: You jump so easily.
B: I hate surprises.
japanese: 心臓（しんぞう）が止（と）まるかと思（おも）った／ドキッとした
chinese: 我心里咯噔一下 (Wǒ xīnli gēdēng yíxià) / 吓我一跳 (Xià wǒ yí tiào)

example:
A: We want a table for two.
B: Sure.
A: Is there a wait?
B: About 45 minutes.
A: We'll go somewhere else.
B: Weekends are busy.
japanese: 待（ま）ち時間（じかん）ある？
chinese: 要排队吗？ (Yào páiduì ma?) / 要等位吗？ (Yào děngwèi ma?)

example:
A: This laptop is cheap.
B: But does it work well?
A: Best bang for the buck.
B: Read the reviews first.
A: They're all five stars.
B: Buy it then.
japanese: コスパがいい
chinese: 性价比高 (Xìngjiàbǐ gāo) / 很划算 (Hěn huásuàn)

example:
A: Did I say that out loud?
B: Yes, everyone heard you.
A: Oops. How embarrassing.
B: It was kinda funny though.
A: I need a filter.
B: No, keep being you.
japanese: 声（こえ）に出（だ）して
chinese: 大声地 (Dàshēng de) / 朗读 (Lǎngdú)

example:
A: Cold beer after work.
B: Oh yeah, it hits the spot.
A: Nothing better.
B: Maybe a burger too?
A: Don't tempt me.
B: Let's do it.
japanese: これこれ、こういうのが欲（ほ）しかったんだ／たまらないね
chinese: 正合我意 (Zhènghéwǒyì) / 太爽了 (Tài shuǎng le) (food/drink)

example:
A: I'm so stressed about finals.
B: Just hang loose, you studied.
A: Easy for you to say.
B: Panicking won't help.
A: I guess.
B: Let's go for a walk.
japanese: 気楽（きらく）に行（い）こうよ
chinese: 放轻松 (Fàng qīngsōng) / 别紧张 (Bié jǐnzhāng)

example:
A: What do they sell?
B: Electronics, clothes, food, you name it.
A: Like a superstore?
B: Basically Amazon in real life.
A: Convenient.
B: But dangerous for my wallet.
japanese: 何（なん）でも言（い）って／ありとあらゆるもの
chinese: 应有尽有 (Yīngyǒujìnyǒu) / 你能想到的都有 (Nǐ néng xiǎngdào de dōu yǒu)

primary: Every cloud has a silver lining
example:
A: I got fired.
B: Every cloud has a silver lining.
A: What's the silver lining here?
B: You hated that boss.
A: True. I'm free.
B: Exactly. Upgrade time.
japanese: 捨（す）てる神（かみ）あれば拾（ひろ）う神（かみ）あり／希望（きぼう）はあるよ
chinese: 塞翁失马焉知非福 (Sàiwēngshīmǎ yānzhīfēifú) / 总有一线希望 (Zǒngyǒu yíxiàn xīwàng)

example:
A: Why didn't you come last night?
B: I was spread too thin with work.
A: You work too much.
B: I need the money.
A: You need a break.
B: Tell my landlord that.
japanese: 手（て）を広（ひろ）げすぎちゃった／キャパオーバーだった
chinese: 分身乏术 (Fēnshēnfáshù) / 忙不过来 (Máng bú guòlái)

example:
A: They're gonna grill me in the meeting.
B: Don't worry, I got your back.
A: Thanks, I'm nervous.
B: We're a team.
A: I appreciate it.
B: Let's crush this.
japanese: 私がついてるよ／援護（えんご）するよ
chinese: 我挺你 (Wǒ tǐng nǐ) / 我是你坚强的后盾 (Wǒ shì nǐ jiānqiáng de hòudùn)

example:
A: Are you done with the intro?
B: Yes. Without further ado, here is our guest.
A: Finally.
B: I like to build suspense.
A: You like to talk.
B: Shh, he's starting.
japanese: 前置（まえお）きはこれくらいにして／早速（さっそく）ですが
chinese: 闲话少说 (Xiánhuàshǎoshuō) / 直接开始 (Zhíjiē kāishǐ)

example:
A: Best pizza in NY?
B: Joe's Pizza, hands down.
A: Prince St is good too.
B: Not even close.
A: Fight me.
B: Let's go eat both and decide.
japanese: 間違いなく／断トツで
chinese: 无疑 (Wúyí) / 肯定 (Kěndìng)

example:
A: Was the test hard?
B: Nah, a walk in the park.
A: I failed it.
B: Oh... awkward.
A: I hate math.
B: Want me to tutor you?
japanese: 朝飯前（あさめしまえ）／楽勝（らくしょう）
chinese: 小菜一碟 (Xiǎocàiyìdié) / 轻而易举 (Qīng'éryìjǔ)

example:
A: Did he show up?
B: No, he flaked.
A: Typical.
B: I'm done with him.
A: Block his number.
B: Already did.
japanese: 姿（すがた）を見（み）せる／現（あらわ）れる
chinese: 出现 (Chūxiàn) / 露面 (Lùmiàn)

example:
A: What's in this box?
B: Just odds and ends.
A: Can we throw it out?
B: No, I might need it.
A: You haven't opened it in years.
B: Today might be the day.
japanese: ガラクタ／半端（はんぱ）モノ
chinese: 零碎东西 (Língsuì dōngxi) / 杂七杂八 (Záqīzábā)

example:
A: Where are my keys?!
B: Calm down.
A: I'm losing it, seriously.
B: They're in your hand.
A: Oh.
B: You need a nap.
japanese: おかしくなりそう／我慢（がまん）の限界（げんかい）だ
chinese: 我要崩溃了 (Wǒ yào bēngkuì le) / 我要疯了 (Wǒ yào fēng le)

example:
A: Yo, why you stuttering? Just spit it out.
B: My bad, I'm just nervous being around her.
A: Did you see him trying to explain that? Straight stuttering.
B: Yeah, he was definitely fumbling over his words.
A: Stop stuttering and tell me what really went down.
B: Okay, chill! I'm trying to get it out.
japanese: ドモる
chinese: 结巴 (Jiēba) / 口吃 (Kǒuchī)

example:
A: My neck is killing me, doc says it's some stenosis thing.
B: Damn, better take it easy with the gym then.
A: I can't even turn my head, this cervical stuff is no joke.
B: You need to see a chiro or something, for real.
A: My cervical disc stenosis is acting up again.
B: Sounds fancy for 'my neck is jacked up'.
japanese: 首（くび）のヘルニア／頚椎（けいつい）狭窄症（きょうさくしょう）
chinese: 颈椎病 (Jǐngzhuībìng) / 颈椎狭窄 (Jǐngzhuī xiázhǎi)

example:
A: Jessica is such a social butterfly, she knows literally everyone here.
B: Fr, she can't walk five feet without dapping someone up.
A: I'm trying to be more of a social butterfly this year.
B: Good luck, you love staying in too much though.
A: Invite Mike, he's a total social butterfly.
B: True, he'll keep the vibe alive.
japanese: 社交家（しゃこうか）／顔（かお）が広（ひろ）い人（ひと）
chinese: 交际花 (Jiāojìhuā) (Use lightly/humorously, can be negative) / 社交达人 (Shèjiāo dárén) (Positive)

example:
A: You gotta expand your social network if you want that job.
B: I know, I need to start hitting up more events.
A: His social network is insane, he knows all the promoters.
B: Yeah, he's definitely plugged in.
A: It's not about what you know, it's about your social network.
B: Facts, connections are everything in this city.
japanese: 人脈（じんみゃく）
chinese: 社交圈 (Shèjiāo quān) / 人脉 (Rénmài)

example:
A: That guy has zero social skills, it was so awkward.
B: I noticed, he just stared at me when I said hi.
A: You need mad social skills to work in PR.
B: for sure, you gotta know how to talk to anyone.
A: Her social skills are on point, she charmed the whole room.
B: She's got that natural rizz.
japanese: コミュ力（りょく）
chinese: 社交能力 (Shèjiāo nénglì) / 会社交 (Huì shèjiāo)

example:
A: Companies act like they care about social responsibility just for clout.
B: Big facts, it's all just marketing usually.
A: We gotta have some social responsibility and clean this park up.
B: I'm down, let's do it for the neighborhood.
A: Social responsibility is huge for Gen Z consumers.
B: Yeah, they don't mess with brands that are shady.
japanese: 社会的（しゃかいてき）責任（せきにん）
chinese: 社会责任 (Shèhuì zérèn)

example:
A: He really doesn't care about societal norms, does he?
B: Nope, he marches to the beat of his own drum.
A: Following societal norms is so boring sometimes.
B: I feel you, sometimes you gotta break the mold.
A: Societal norms say we should settle down, but I'm just living.
B: Do you, don't worry about what people expect.
japanese: 世間（せけん）の常識（じょうしき）
chinese: 社会规范 (Shèhuì guīfàn) / 世俗眼光 (Shìsú yǎnguāng)

meaning: 특별히 더 신경 쓰다 / 한 발 더 뛰다
example:
A: She always goes the extra mile for her clients.
B: That's why she's the top earner in the office.
A: I'm gonna go the extra mile on this project to impress the boss.
B: Secure that promotion, I see you.
A: You didn't have to get me a gift too, you really went the extra mile.
B: You know I got you, gotta treat my friends right.
japanese: 期待（きたい）以上（いじょう）の働（はたら）きをする／一歩（いっぽ）踏（ふ）み込（こ）んでやる
chinese: 加倍努力 (Jiābèi nǔlì) / 多做一点 (Duō zuò yìdiǎn)

example:
A: Let's get the ball rolling on this trip planning.
B: bet, I'll start looking at flights tonight.
A: We need to get the ball rolling if we want to finish by Friday.
B: Alright, I'm opening the doc right now.
A: Who's gonna get the ball rolling on the group chat?
B: I got it, I'll add everyone now.
japanese: 始（はじ）めよう／取（と）り掛（か）かろう
chinese: 把事做起来 (Bǎ shì zuò qǐlái) / 启动 (Qǐdòng)

example:
A: I've never had oyster, but I'll give it a shot.
B: You might like it, just put some hot sauce on it.
A: You think I should apply? I'm not qualified.
B: Just give it a shot, you never know.
A: I'm gonna give it a shot and ask for her number.
B: Do it, bro! Shoot your shot.
japanese: やってみなよ／試（ため）してみなよ
chinese: 试一试 (Shìyíshì) / 闯一闯 (Chuǎngyìchuǎng)

example:
A: He went out of his way to drive me to the airport.
B: That's a real friend right there.
A: Don't go out of your way if it's too much trouble.
B: Nah, it's cool, I'm headed that way anyway.
A: She really went out of her way to make me feel welcome.
B: She's sweet like that, always looking out.
japanese: わざわざ〜する／無理（むり）してやる
chinese: 特意 (Tèyì) / 费尽周折 (Fèijìnzhōuzhé)

example:
A: We're trying to get this startup off the ground.
B: The beginning is always the hardest grind.
A: Once this project gets off the ground, it's gonna be huge.
B: Facts, I can see the potential.
A: It's hard to get a music career off the ground in this city.
B: Too much competition, everyone's a rapper.
japanese: 軌道（きどう）に乗（の）る／始動（しどう）する
chinese: 取得进展 (Qǔdé jìnzhǎn) / 顺利起步 (Shùnlì qǐbù)

example:
A: I'm just creating peace for the sake of the family.
B: I feel that, gotta keep the drama low at Thanksgiving.
A: Let's just agree for the sake of finishing this meeting.
B: Please, I wanna go home already.
A: He quit smoking for the sake of his health.
B: Good for him, that stuff is bad news.
japanese: 〜のために
chinese: 为了...起见 (Wèile... qǐjiàn) / 看在...份上 (Kànzài... fènshǎng)

example:
A: I'm crashing on my friend's couch for the time being.
B: Until you find a new spot? That's decent of him.
A: Let's stick to this plan for the time being.
B: Cool, we can switch it up later if we need to.
A: The shop is closed for the time being.
B: Dang, I really wanted a bagel.
japanese: 当分（とうぶん）の間（あいだ）／差（さ）し当（あ）たり
chinese: 暂时 (Zànshí) / 目前 (Mùqián)

example:
A: Let's eat something healthy for a change.
B: You mean not pizza? Who are you?
A: It's nice to see you smiling for a change.
B: Shut up, I smile sometimes!
A: We decided to go upstate for a change.
B: Nice, get some fresh air away from the city.
japanese: 気分（きぶん）転換（てんかん）に／たまには
chinese: 换换口味 (Huànhuan kǒuwèi) / 改变一下 (Gǎibiàn yíxià)

example:
A: Do you still talk to him?
B: From time to time, but not like before.
A: I like to treat myself to a spa day from time to time.
B: Self-care is important, I gotta do that more.
A: It gets really loud here from time to time.
B: Yeah, that's city living for you.
japanese: 時々（ときどき）／たまに
chinese: 偶尔 (Ǒu'ěr) / 时不时 (Shíbùshí)

meaning: 좋을 때나 나쁠 때나 / 산전수전 다 겪으며
example:
A: They've been together through thick and thin.
B: That's real love, staying through the hard times.
A: My best friend has been with me through thick and thin.
B: Keep those people close, they're rare.
A: We gotta stick together through thick and thin.
B: Fo sho, squad for life.
japanese: どんな時（とき）も／良（い）い時（とき）も悪（わる）い時（とき）も
chinese: 同甘共苦 (Tónggāngòngkǔ) / 风雨同舟 (Fēngyǔtóngzhōu)

example:
A: Beyonce is a straight-up force of nature.
B: Absolutely, nobody does it like her.
A: When he gets mad, he's like a force of nature.
B: Yeah, I stay out of his way when he's heated.
A: That storm was a force of nature, so scary.
B: Mother Nature doesn't play.
japanese: 圧倒的（あっとうてき）な存在（そんざい）／嵐（あらし）のような人（ひと）
chinese: 不可抗拒的力量 (Bùkěkàngjù de lìliàng) / 鬼才 (Guǐcái) (person)

example:
A: He quit smoking by sheer force of will.
B: That's tough, respect to him.
A: You need strong force of will to finish a marathon.
B: For real, my legs would give out at mile 2.
A: Her force of will is scary proficient.
B: She gets what she wants, period.
japanese: 意志（いし）の力（ちから）
chinese: 意志力 (Yìzhìlì) / 毅力 (Yìlì)

example:
A: He won the room over just by force of personality.
B: Yeah, he walks in and owns the place.
A: You can't ignore her, she has such a force of personality.
B: She definitely commands attention.
A: It takes a certain force of personality to lead like that.
B: Born leader vibes.
japanese: 人間（にんげん）力（りょく）／カリスマ性（せい）
chinese: 人格魅力 (Réngé mèilì) / 气场 (Qìchǎng)

example:
A: The force of impact totaled the car.
B: Damn, everyone okay though?
A: You could feel the force of impact from the bass.
B: That concert was shaking the whole block.
A: The news hit with the force of impact of a bomb.
B: Everyone was shook.
japanese: 衝撃（しょうげき）
chinese: 冲击力 (Chōngjīlì) / 震撼力 (Zhènhànlì)

example:
A: *Sneezes* Ugh, my allergies are acting up.
B: Bless you! The pollen count is high today.
A: I can't breathe, my allergies are acting up so bad.
B: Did you take a Zyrtec?
A: My eyes are so itchy, allergies are acting up.
B: You look high, go wash your face.
japanese: アレルギーが出（で）ちゃって
chinese: 我过敏犯了 (Wǒ guòmǐn fàn le) / 过敏又发作了 (Guòmǐn yòu fāzuò le)

meaning: 나 좀 내버려 둬 / 잔소리 좀 그만해
example:
A: Did you finish the report yet?
B: Get off my back! I'm doing it right now.
A: I'm just asking! You don't have to snap.
B: You've asked me five times, just chill.
A: Mom just won't get off my back about getting married.
B: Parents stay stressing us out.
japanese: 放（ほう）っておいて／うるさいな
chinese: 别烦我了 (Bié fán wǒ le) / 饶了我吧 (Ráo le wǒ ba)

primary: Lets pick up where we left off
meaning: 아까 하던 얘기 계속하자 / 여기서부터 다시 시작하자
example:
A: Sorry I had to take that call. Where were we?
B: Let's pick up where we left off, discussing the budget.
A: We ran out of time yesterday, let's pick up where we left off.
B: Cool, pull up the slide deck.
A: I wanna pick up where we left off on our date.
B: Smooth... drinks at 8?
japanese: 話（はなし）の続（つづ）きをしよう
chinese: 我们接着刚才的说 (Wǒmen jiēzhe gāngcái de shuō) / 继续刚才的话题 (Jìxù gāngcái de huàtí)

primary: I just bumped my elbow on the doorframe
example:
A: Oww! I just bumped my elbow on the doorframe.
B: That funny bone pain is the worst!
A: You okay? You winced hard.
B: Yeah, just bumped my elbow on the doorframe. My arm is tingling.
A: Watch out for that doorframe.
B: Too late, just bumped my elbow. RIP my arm.
japanese: ドア枠（わく）に肘（ひじ）ぶつけた
chinese: 我胳膊肘撞门框上了 (Wǒ gēbozhǒu zhuàng ménkuàng shàng le) / 磕到麻筋了 (Kē dào májīn le)

example:
A: You didn't give up even when it got hard. You have grit.
B: Momma raised a fighter.
A: I respect how you handled that loss. You have grit.
B: Fall down seven times, stand up eight.
A: To make it in NYC, you gotta have grit.
B: Facts, this city will chew you up otherwise.
japanese: 根性（こんじょう）あるね
chinese: 你有毅力 (Nǐ yǒu yìlì) / 你很顽强 (Nǐ hěn wánqiáng)

example:
A: You really talked back to the boss? You have guts.
B: Someone had to say it.
A: I can't believe you jumped off that cliff. You have guts.
B: It was a rush!
A: Asking for a raise on your first day? You have guts.
B: Know your worth, add tax.
japanese: 度胸（どきょう）あるね
chinese: 你有种 (Nǐ yǒuzhǒng) / 胆子真大 (Dǎnzi zhēn dà)

example:
A: You want to try that new fusion spot?
B: Always down, I'm a foodie.
A: She posts food pics all day.
B: Yeah, she claims 'I'm a foodie' in her bio.
A: Since I'm a foodie, NYC is paradise.
B: Too many options, not enough stomach space.
japanese: 食（た）べるの大好（だいす）きなんだ／食通（しょくつう）なんだ
chinese: 我是个吃货 (Wǒ shì gè chīhuò) / 我很爱吃 (Wǒ hěn ài chī)

meaning: 이제 더 이상은 못 참아 / 이게 한계야
example:
A: He flaked on plans again.
B: That's the last straw, block his number.
A: If my boss yells one more time, it's the last straw.
B: Don't quit without a backup plan though.
A: The wifi cut out during the game. It's the last straw.
B: Time to switch providers.
japanese: もう我慢（がまん）できない／仏（ほとけ）の顔（かお）も三度（さんど）まで
chinese: 这是最后一根稻草 (Zhè shì zuìhòu yì gēn dàocǎo) / 我忍无可忍了 (Wǒ rěnwúkěrěn le)

example:
A: I'm bored. Wanna catch a movie later?
B: Sure, what's playing?
A: Work was stress. Wanna catch a movie later to unwind?
B: I'm down, let's get popcorn too.
A: Wanna catch a movie later?
B: Nah, let's just Netflix and chill.
japanese: 後（あと）で映画（えいが）でも観（み）ない？
chinese: 晚点去看个电影？ (Wǎndiǎn qù kàn gè diànyǐng?) / 一会儿去看戏？ (Yíhuìr qù kànxì?)

example:
A: You think it's gonna rain?
B: With those clouds? It seems a bit likely.
A: Is he gonna get the promotion?
B: It seems a bit likely, the boss loves him.
A: She might flake.
B: Knowing her? It seems a bit likely.
japanese: ありえなくもないね／可能性（かのうせい）はあるね
chinese: 这倒是很有可能 (Zhè dàoshì hěn yǒu kěnéng) / 看起来挺像那么回事 (Kànqǐlái tǐng xiàng nàme huí shì)

meaning: 좀 오바한 것 같더라 / 과장된 것 같아
example:
A: Did you believe his story?
B: Nah, it seemed a bit exaggerated.
A: Her reaction was wild.
B: Yeah, it seemed a bit exaggerated for just a spilled drink.
A: The news report made it sound like a war zone.
B: Clickbait, bro. It seemed a bit exaggerated.
japanese: ちょっと話（はなし）盛（も）ってる気（き）がする
chinese: 有点言过其实了 (Yǒudiǎn yánguòqíshí le) / 太夸张了 (Tài kuāzhāng le)

example:
A: Is he coming or not?
B: I don't know, he's being so wishy washy.
A: Don't be wishy washy, pick a restaurant!
B: Everything sounds good though!
A: I hate dealing with wishy washy clients.
B: Same, just sign the contract already.
japanese: 煮（に）え切（き）らない／優柔不断（ゆうじゅうふだん）
chinese: 优柔寡断 (Yōuróuguǎduàn) / 磨磨唧唧 (Mómōjīji)

meaning: 일단 비밀로 해 / 입 닫고 있어
example:
A: I'm planning a surprise party for her.
B: details? And keep a lid on it.
A: Did you hear about the merger?
B: Yeah, but keep a lid on it until it's official.
A: I don't want everyone knowing my business.
B: Don't worry, I'll keep a lid on it.
japanese: ここだけの話（はなし）にしておいて／秘密（ひみつ）にしておいて
chinese: 先保密 (Xiān bǎomì) / 别说出去 (Bié shuō chūqù)

primary: I'm not the type to regret things
meaning: 나 원래 후회 잘 안 해 / 뒤끝 없는 스타일이야
example:
A: Do you wish you hadn't moved here?
B: Nah, I'm not the type to regret things.
A: That tattoo is wild.
B: Whatever, I'm not the type to regret things.
A: You burnt a bridge there.
B: It is what it is. I'm not the type to regret things.
japanese: 後悔（こうかい）しないタイプなんだ
chinese: 我不是那种会后悔的人 (Wǒ búshì nàzhǒng huì hòuhuǐ de rén) / 我做事不后悔 (Wǒ zuòshì bú hòuhuǐ)

primary: I am at a loss for words
meaning: 뭐라 할 말이 없네 / 어이가 없네
example:
A: Did you see that outfit?
B: I am at a loss for words. It was... interesting.
A: The view from here is insane.
B: Wow, I am at a loss for words. So beautiful.
A: He actually said that?
B: Yes, I am at a loss for words. The audacity.
japanese: 開（あ）いた口（くち）が塞（ふさ）がらない／言葉（ことば）を失（うしな）ったよ
chinese: 我也无语了 (Wǒ yě wúyǔ le) / 我都不知道说什么好了 (Wǒ dōu bù zhīdào shuō shénme hǎo le)

meaning: 무슨 일 있어? / 뭐 찜찜한 거 있어?
example:
A: You've been quiet all night. Is something bothering you?
B: just tired, honestly.
A: Is something bothering you? You keep checking your phone.
B: Waiting for a text, that's all.
A: You seem annoyed. Is something bothering you?
B: Yeah, actually, we need to talk.
japanese: 何（なに）かあった？／気（き）になることでも？
chinese: 有心事吗？ (Yǒu xīnshì ma?) / 遇到什么麻烦了吗？ (Yùdào shénme máfan le ma?)

primary: It's nothing. Don't worry about it.
example:
A: What did you say?
B: It's nothing. Don't worry about it.
A: Are you mad?
B: Nah, it's nothing. Don't worry about it.
A: Sorry I broke your pen.
B: It's nothing. Don't worry about it, I have ten more.
japanese: なんでもないよ、気（き）にしないで
chinese: 没事，别担心 (Méishì, bié dānxīn) / 没啥事，别往心里去 (Méi shá shì, bié wǎng xīnli qù)

meaning: 고통받느니 죽는 게 낫지 / 힘들게 사느니 죽고 말지
example:
A: We have to walk 20 blocks in the rain.
B: I'd rather die than suffer through that. Uber?
A: You want to watch that 4-hour documentary?
B: I'd rather die than suffer that boredom.
A: Drama with the ex again?
B: Ugh, I'd rather die than suffer his nonsense.
japanese: 苦（くる）しむくらいなら死（し）んだ方（ほう）がマシだ
chinese: 我宁死也不愿受这罪 (Wǒ nìngsǐ yě búyuàn shòu zhè zuì) / 让我受罪还不如杀了我 (Ràng wǒ shòuzuì hái bùrú shā le wǒ)

example:
A: How was the interview?
B: It was so nerve racking, I was shaking.
A: Waiting for the results is nerve racking.
B: Tell me about it, my heart is pounding.
A: First dates are always nerve racking.
B: Just be yourself, you got this.
japanese: ハラハラする／神経（しんけい）すり減（へ）らす
chinese: 伤神 (Shāngshén) / 让人提心吊胆 (Ràng rén tíxīndiàodǎn)

example:
A: Why are you being so nice to Dad?
B: Trying to butter him up so I can borrow the car.
A: She's totally trying to butter up the boss.
B: Yeah, she wants that promotion bad.
A: Don't try to butter me up, you're still grounded.
B: Worth a shot though, right?
japanese: ゴマをする／おだてる
chinese: 讨好 (Tǎohǎo) / 巴结 (Bājie)

example:
A: Look at him bringing coffee for everyone.
B: Total brown nose move.
A: Nobody likes a brown nose.
B: But the boss loves him, so who's winning?
A: Stop being a brown nose and have an opinion.
B: I'm just being a team player!
japanese: ご機嫌取（きげんと）り／腰巾着（こしぎんちゃく）
chinese: 马屁精 (Mǎpìjīng) / 舔狗 (Tiǎngǒu) (slang, harsh)

example:
A: You'll never guess who I bumped into today.
B: Who? Your ex?
A: I bumped into Sarah at the bodega.
B: No way, how is she doing?
A: Always awkward when you bump into a coworker on the weekend.
B: Pretend you didn't see them. Valid strategy.
japanese: ばったり会（あ）った
chinese: 偶遇 (Ǒuyù) / 碰见 (Pèngjiàn)

example:
A: Sorry, I think I bumped against your table.
B: It's cool, no water spilled.
A: The subway was so crowded, I bumped against like ten people.
B: Rush hour vibes, gotta love it.
A: I bumped against the wall in the dark.
B: Ouch, you okay?
japanese: ぶつかった
chinese: 撞到 (Zhuàngdào) / 磕到 (Kēdào)

primary: I bumped my toes on the doorframe
example:
A: *Screams silently*
B: What happened? You look in pain.
A: I bumped my toes on the doorframe.
B: The worst pain known to man. RIP.
A: I need steel-toed boots in this house.
B: Clumsy much?
japanese: ドア枠（わく）に足（あし）の指（ゆび）ぶつけた
chinese: 我脚趾撞门框上了 (Wǒ jiǎozhǐ zhuàng ménkuàng shàng le) / 踢到门框了，疼死 (Tī dào ménkuàng le, téng sǐ)

example:
A: He let her cancel again?
B: Yeah, he's such a pushover.
A: Don't be a pushover, tell them no.
B: It's hard, I hate conflict.
A: They treat the substitute teacher like a pushover.
B: Kids can be ruthless.
japanese: チョロい人（ひと）／言（い）いなりになる人（ひと）
chinese: 软柿子 (Ruǎnshìzi) / 耳根子软的人 (Ěrgēnzi ruǎn de rén)

example:
A: That guy is cute. Is he spoken for?
B: I think he has a girlfriend.
A: Are you spoken for, or can I buy you a drink?
B: I'm spoken for, but thanks for the offer.
A: Everyone at this party is spoken for.
B: Single life is rough out here.
japanese: 誰（だれ）か付（つ）き合（あ）ってる人（ひと）いる？
chinese: 名花有主了吗？ (Mínghuāyǒuzhǔ le ma?) / 有对象了吗？ (Yǒu duìxiàng le ma?)

meaning: 걔 사진 찍는 거 싫어해 / 카메라 공포증 있어
example:
A: Let's take a selfie!
B: Don't ask Mike, he is pretty camera shy.
A: Why are there no photos of him online?
B: He is pretty camera shy, likes his privacy.
A: He hid his face again.
B: Yeah, he is pretty camera shy.
japanese: 彼（かれ）、写真（しゃしん）嫌（ぎら）いなんだ
chinese: 他挺害羞的，不喜欢拍照 (Tā tǐng hàixiū de, bù xǐhuan pāizhào) / 他有点镜头恐惧症 (Tā yǒudiǎn jìngtóu kǒngjùzhèng)

example:
A: My feed is still showing posts from yesterday, what's wrong?
B: Just pull down to refresh, it probably just needs a quick sync.
A: I already tried that, but it's still stuck on the same photo.
B: Maybe your wifi is trippin'. Try switching to data.
A: Oh, that worked. Now I see all the new drama.
B: Perfect. Now you can get back to being a hater, haha.
japanese: 引（ひ）っ張（ぱ）って更新（こうしん）
chinese: 下拉刷新 (Xiàlā shuāxīn)

example:
A: I'm quitting my job on Friday, but not a word to anyone yet.
B: Wait, what? Are you serious? Where are you going?
A: I got an offer from that startup in Brooklyn, but it's not official.
B: That's huge! I promise, my lips are sealed. Not a word.
A: Thank you. I don't want any corporate drama before I leave.
B: I got you. Your secret is totally safe with me.
japanese: 誰（だれ）にも言（い）っちゃダメだよ
chinese: 一个字都别说 (Yí gè zì dōu bié shuō) / 守口如瓶 (Shǒukǒurúpíng)

meaning: 알았어, 더 말 안 해도 이해했어 (바로 할게)
example:
A: Can you grab some ice on your way to the party tonight?
B: Say less, I'll pick up two bags and some extra cups too.
A: You're a lifesaver, everyone always forgets the ice.
B: I've been to enough NYC house parties to know the drill.
A: True. See you around 9 then?
B: I'll be there. I'll text you when I'm pulling up.
japanese: 任（まか）せて／言（い）わなくても分（わ）かってる
chinese: 懂了，不用多说 (Dǒng le, búyòng duōshuō) / 收到 (Shōudào)

example:
A: You need to clean your room right now.
B: Why do I always have to do it? It's not even that messy.
A: Don't sass me, just get it done.
B: I'm just saying, it's unfair!
A: One more word and you're grounded.
B: Fine, I'm going.
japanese: 口答（くちごた）えしないで
chinese: 别跟我顶嘴 (Bié gēn wǒ dǐngzuǐ) / 别跟我耍嘴皮子 (Bié gēn wǒ shuǎ zuǐpízi)
